title.value: A Large-Scale Exploratory Study of Android Sports Apps in the Google Play Store
title.justification: This is the paper's title as given by the authors.
title.quote: A Large-Scale Exploratory Study of Android Sports Apps in the Google Play Store

extractions.description: This paper investigates a large number of Android sports apps available in the Google Play Store. It aims to understand the characteristics of these apps, the topics in user reviews, and the factors contributing to negative user opinions. The study combines qualitative and quantitative analyses, covering over 2,000 sports apps and their reviews, and provides insights for sports app developers.

type.justification: The study involves empirical data analysis, including the extraction of statistics from app reviews and surveys of app characteristics.
type.quote: This work aims to study a large number of apps from a single category (i.e., the sports category). Our work can provide two folds contributions: 1) identifying insights that are specific to tens of thousands of sports apps, and 2) providing empirical evidence on the benefits of analyzing apps in a specific category.

name.justification: The study focuses on mobile applications, specifically sports apps available in the Google Play Store, examining their characteristics and user reviews.
name.quote: In this work, we study a carefully curated set of 2,058 sports apps in the Google Play Store.

name.justification: The study uses natural language processing techniques like topic modeling and sentiment analysis to analyze user reviews.
name.quote: Our studied 2,058 sports apps have a total of 740,226 reviews. It is difficult to manually examine all these reviews. Thus, we use automatic topic modeling to extract the topics from these reviews.

name.justification: The study aims to identify the aspects that contribute to negative opinions of users, which is central to software quality.
name.quote: Finally, we observed that users are mainly complaining about the advertisements and quality (e.g., bugs, content quality, streaming quality) of sports apps.

name.justification: The paper mentions that it starts analyzing apps based on the top-rated sports apps from AppBrain.
name.quote: From AppBrain, we downloaded a dataset of top-rated 500 free apps[9] in the US region3 . According to the analysis of mobile app usage in 2020, the US had the highest number of sports app downloads

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is mentioned without a reference to a specific paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: From AppBrain, we downloaded a dataset of top-rated 500 free apps[9] in the US region

name.justification: The paper uses MALLET for topic modeling in its analysis of app reviews.
name.quote: We employed the Gensim wrapper for the Mallet implementation of the LDA topic modeling algorithm

referenced_paper_title.justification: MALLET is a well-known toolkit and does not require specific citation.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Mallet [28], a standalone tool, serves as the underlying framework, while Gensim [29] provides a convenient interface for utilizing its functionalities.

name.justification: The paper uses the VADER sentiment analysis tool to analyze the sentiment of user reviews.
name.quote: We use NLTKâ€™s pre-trained sentimental analysis library called VADER (Valence Aware Dictionary and sEntiment Reasoner)

aliases: Valence Aware Dictionary and sEntiment Reasoner

referenced_paper_title.value: VADER: A Parsimonious Rule-based Model for Sentiment Analysis of Social Media Text
referenced_paper_title.justification: The VADER library is referenced with its original paper title.
referenced_paper_title.quote: VADER appears to be the best suit for the language used in social media [44], which are short sentences with some slang and abbreviations expected to be similar in user reviews. The median review length of the entire review corpus under study is 12 words per review sentence. For each review ( Google reviews have a max limitation of 500 characters) that we have in our dataset, VADER analyses the sentences and returns four different scores for each review: a negativity score (neg), a neutrality score (neu), a positivity score (pos), and a compound score (compound).
